item.title: By: Sean McLaughlin
item.dc:creator: Sean McLaughlin
item.description: How gratifying to hear that there are friendships being forged, discussions taking place. Mormons who are deep into their faith tend to have a great deal of respect and feel a kinship with the Jewish faith, traditions, teachings, and practices. We embrace truth where it is found, and in our eyes, there is no room for anything but admiration and respect for the truth of Judaism. We may have "our take" on things of course, but in the way of family, heritage, and core values and beliefs, we have much to share together and celebrate together. Love and respect!

item.title: By: Lindsay
item.dc:creator: Lindsay
item.description:
In reply to <a href="https://kavvanah.wordpress.com/2011/03/15/orthodox-big-love-for-mormons/#comment-2907">M.Efron</a>.
M. There are a few points of LDS doctrine, in which you are misinformed. We don't believe that JHWH is a subgod. He is a member of the Godhead. Do you believe that other religions consider JHWH a subgod because he is a member of their trinity? Elohim or God the Father is also a member of that Godhead, but is not the godhead. The Godhead is composed of G-D the Father, his son JHWH, and the Holy Ghost....similar to the trinity, but also different. But in no way do we consider JHWH to be a subgod. We also don't believe that "all human beings have been gods before being born and will be again". We believe that all humans existed before this life, but we were not gods, we were spirit children of our heavenly father (Elohim). We also don't believe that all humans will become gods. We believe that this life is a chance for us to become like G-d. And that if we obey his commandments, through the atonement of Christ, can become like our Heavenly Father. Not too difficult or outrageous of a claim, doesn't every parent seek for their children to have all that they have? Doesn't every parent want their children to be like them (well the good characteristics :-) ?

item.title: By: M.Efron
item.dc:creator: M.Efron
item.description:
Mormons are polytheistic religion and believe that JHWH is a subgod to a Godhead called Elohim. Elohim has his residence near an unknown star called Kolob. Elohim has a wife, too. All human beings have been gods before being born and will be again. Mormons also say that the Hebrew Bible verifies all this.
Has the fact that there is only one God, not myriads, any importance to Judaism ? One can choose friends among football fans or swimmers without much thought to their beliefs, but talking about relations between religions, it would be well to remember what one stands for. Otherwise it might even make ignorant people think that as religion Judaism and Mormonism are like, even though they differ like day and night.

item.title: By: Mark Paredes
item.dc:creator: Mark Paredes
item.description:
In reply to <a href="https://kavvanah.wordpress.com/2011/03/15/orthodox-big-love-for-mormons/#comment-2809">Jon Baker</a>.
Jon - Unfortunately, you have no idea what you're talking about re replacement theology and Mormons. Here's my blog post on the topic: http://www.jewishjournal.com/jews_and_mormons/item/replacement_theology_mormons_and_the_amish_39101204/ Also, your priesthood terminology is off, and our faith is not based on Masonic rituals. One of the main temple rituals involves the washing and anointing ritual administered to Aaron and his priests, which is explained in Exodus. Just curious: would you like a Mormon to poke fun at the tallit katan on a website? I'm very disappointed to see such profound ignorance on display on a Jewish website, even if it is only a silly comment. As the saying goes, a little learning is a dangerous thing.

item.title: By: Jon Baker
item.dc:creator: Jon Baker
item.description:
To amplify Mordechai's point: Do these OU rabbis know that the Mormons hold to a strong replacement theology? At different levels of their development, many/most boys/men are known as Aaronide Priests and then Melchizedek Priests. There may be a third intermediate level called Abrahamic priesthood.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patriarchal_priesthood http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Priesthood_%28Mormonism%29
Debbie (Mrs. B) has read a number of books about Mormonism, as it is the original American (in many senses) Religion based on a bad SF novel, as well as Masonic rituals. E.g. the special underwear is basically a t-shirt with the Masonic Square (a V) over one breast and the Compass (a caret) over the other.

item.description: Mordechai- I think you may be onto something that I did not grasp at first. I doubt that most of the Orthodox rabbis know that most Christians do not consider Mormons Christians. They probably think they are another brand of Protestantism. I also doubt that these rabbis know that Mormons think God has an actual body, can impregnate people, was once a person, was not God for all eternity. (There is lots of subtleties, apologetics, and modern readings of these concepts). Their definition of God would be more questionable halakhicly than these rabbis realize. ve ACM"L
